Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
What are the key ideas behind unsupervised learning?

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.
How does transformers and self-attention relate to other concepts?

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.
Explain overfitting and underfitting?

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
Give a concise definition of feature stores.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
How does model-centric vs data-centric iteration relate to other concepts?

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about pooling layers?
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.
Give an example of supervised learning

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.
Give an example of train–serve skew

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.
How does real-time machine learning relate to other concepts?

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

How does train–serve skew relate to other concepts?

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.
Describe a practical use case where ML monitoring is applied?

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
How does AutoML relate to other concepts?

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.
What are the key ideas behind LSTM networks?
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
How does ML agents relate to other concepts?

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.
Why is overfitting and underfitting important in modern machine learning systems?

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
Why is LSTM networks important in modern machine learning systems?
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
Why is reinforcement learning important in modern machine learning systems?

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.
Give an example of unsupervised learning

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.
Give a concise definition of logistic regression?

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.
How does convolutional neural networks relate to other concepts?

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.
How does LSTM networks relate to other concepts?
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
Give a concise definition of model-centric vs data-centric iteration.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

Describe a practical use case where serverless ML is applied?

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
Why is recurrent neural networks important in modern machine learning systems?

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.
How does logistic regression relate to other concepts?

Describe a practical use case where backpropagation is applied?

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about reinforcement learning?

What are the advantages of understanding real-time machine learning well?

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.
Give a concise definition of serverless ML?

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
Explain pooling layers
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.
Why is transformers and self-attention important in modern machine learning systems?

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.
Explain linear regression?

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.
Give an example of activation functions

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.
Why is train–serve skew important in modern machine learning systems?

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.
What are the advantages of understanding softmax regression well?

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about serverless ML?

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
Explain real-time machine learning.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.
What are the key ideas behind reinforcement learning?

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.
Give an example of feature stores

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
What are the advantages of understanding ML agents well?

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.
What are the key ideas behind ML monitoring?

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
Give a concise definition of backpropagation.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.
Give an example of linear regression

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.
Explain logistic regression

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

Give a concise definition of supervised learning.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.
Give a concise definition of ML monitoring.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
Why is feature stores important in modern machine learning systems?

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
Explain transformers and self-attention

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.
How does LSTM networks relate to other concepts?
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

What are the advantages of understanding real-time machine learning well?

Explain model-centric vs data-centric iteration.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.
Describe a practical use case where overfitting and underfitting is applied.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
Give an example of convolutional neural networks

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.

Explain serverless ML

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
Give an example of train–serve skew

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.
What are the advantages of understanding reinforcement learning well?

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.
How does ML monitoring relate to other concepts?

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
How does softmax regression relate to other concepts?

Give a concise definition of gradient descent.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.
Describe a practical use case where feedforward neural networks is applied.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.
Explain linear regression

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

Give an example of logistic regression

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.

How does activation functions relate to other concepts?

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

What are the advantages of understanding backpropagation well?

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.
Explain logistic regression

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.
Give an example of LSTM networks
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
Give an example of overfitting and underfitting

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
Why is linear regression important in modern machine learning systems?

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.
Explain softmax regression.

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.
Describe a practical use case where reinforcement learning is applied.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about softmax regression?

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.
Why is ML monitoring important in modern machine learning systems?

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
What are the advantages of understanding unsupervised learning well?

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.
Give an example of pooling layers
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.
What are the advantages of understanding linear regression well?

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.
How does LSTM networks relate to other concepts?
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
What are the advantages of understanding train–serve skew well?

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.
What are the key ideas behind feature stores?

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
Give a concise definition of logistic regression.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.
What are the key ideas behind feedforward neural networks?

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.
Describe a practical use case where activation functions is applied?

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.
Describe a practical use case where model-centric vs data-centric iteration is applied.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.
How does feedforward neural networks relate to other concepts?

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

Give a concise definition of reinforcement learning.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
Explain overfitting and underfitting.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
Give a concise definition of serverless ML.

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
Give an example of AutoML

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.
What are the advantages of understanding supervised learning well?

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.
What are the key ideas behind ML monitoring?

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
Describe a practical use case where serverless ML is applied.

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
What are the advantages of understanding recurrent neural networks well?

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.
Give a concise definition of unsupervised learning?

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.
Explain train–serve skew

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.
What are the advantages of understanding ML agents well?

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.
What are the key ideas behind linear regression?

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.
Give a concise definition of reinforcement learning.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.
Give a concise definition of gradient descent.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.
What are the key ideas behind convolutional neural networks?

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about gradient descent?

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.
Give an example of linear regression

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.
How does overfitting and underfitting relate to other concepts?

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about model-centric vs data-centric iteration?

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.
Give a concise definition of pooling layers.
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.
What are the advantages of understanding overfitting and underfitting well?

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
Why is real-time machine learning important in modern machine learning systems?

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.
How does feature stores relate to other concepts?

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
What are the key ideas behind real-time machine learning?

Explain transformers and self-attention.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
Explain LSTM networks
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
Explain softmax regression

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

Explain train–serve skew

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.
Give an example of activation functions

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

What are the advantages of understanding recurrent neural networks well?

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.
What are the key ideas behind feedforward neural networks?

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
Give an example of activation functions

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.
Explain unsupervised learning

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.
Give an example of serverless ML

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about recurrent neural networks?

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.
Explain reinforcement learning?

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.
Describe a practical use case where ML agents is applied.

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.
Why is reinforcement learning important in modern machine learning systems?

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.
Explain pooling layers
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.
Explain backpropagation

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.
How does softmax regression relate to other concepts?

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

How does feature stores relate to other concepts?

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about overfitting and underfitting?

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.
Describe a practical use case where linear regression is applied.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.
Why is transformers and self-attention important in modern machine learning systems?

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about pooling layers?
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.
Describe a practical use case where LSTM networks is applied.
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
Give an example of unsupervised learning

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.
Explain unsupervised learning

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.
Give an example of softmax regression

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.
Explain backpropagation.

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about model-centric vs data-centric iteration?

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

Give an example of supervised learning

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.
Give a concise definition of gradient descent.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

Explain feature stores.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

Give an example of train–serve skew

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.
Explain supervised learning.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.
What are the key ideas behind gradient descent?

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.
How does supervised learning relate to other concepts?

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.
Why is linear regression important in modern machine learning systems?

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.
Give an example of backpropagation

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.
Give a concise definition of model-centric vs data-centric iteration.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.
What are the key ideas behind serverless ML?

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
What are the key ideas behind transformers and self-attention?

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.
How does overfitting and underfitting relate to other concepts?

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
What are the advantages of understanding overfitting and underfitting well?

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
How does ML monitoring relate to other concepts?

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
Why is transformers and self-attention important in modern machine learning systems?

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.
Give an example of logistic regression

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.
Explain LSTM networks
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
Why is pooling layers important in modern machine learning systems?
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.
Explain train–serve skew

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.
Why is LSTM networks important in modern machine learning systems?
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
Give a concise definition of feature stores.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
What are the key ideas behind feedforward neural networks?

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.
Give an example of real-time machine learning

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
How does softmax regression relate to other concepts?

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.

Give an example of recurrent neural networks

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.
Give a concise definition of overfitting and underfitting.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about softmax regression?

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about pooling layers?
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.
What are the advantages of understanding ML agents well?

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.
Describe a practical use case where ML monitoring is applied.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
Why is LSTM networks important in modern machine learning systems?
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
Give a concise definition of linear regression?

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.
Explain unsupervised learning

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.

Describe a practical use case where supervised learning is applied.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.
Give an example of AutoML

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.
Why is logistic regression important in modern machine learning systems?

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.
Describe a practical use case where unsupervised learning is applied?

What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about logistic regression?

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about transformers and self-attention?

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.
Explain activation functions

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.
How does LSTM networks relate to other concepts?
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
Explain model-centric vs data-centric iteration.

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

How does feature stores relate to other concepts?

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

Why is ML monitoring important in modern machine learning systems?

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about unsupervised learning?

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.
Describe a practical use case where gradient descent is applied.

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about recurrent neural networks?

Recurrent neural networks (RNNs) process sequences by maintaining a hidden state that evolves over time. They share parameters across timesteps and can model temporal dependencies in data such as text or time series.
What are the key ideas behind real-time machine learning?

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.
Explain unsupervised learning

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.
Explain feature stores.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
Explain LSTM networks.
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about model-centric vs data-centric iteration?

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.
How does AutoML relate to other concepts?

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.

Give an example of softmax regression

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about serverless ML?

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
Give a concise definition of overfitting and underfitting.

Overfitting occurs when a model fits noise in the training data and fails to generalize. Underfitting occurs when the model is too simple to capture the underlying pattern. Good ML practice aims to balance bias and variance to achieve low generalization error.
Explain feedforward neural networks.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about pooling layers?
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.
Give a concise definition of feature stores.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
How does AutoML relate to other concepts?

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.
Explain reinforcement learning

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.
Explain AutoML.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.
What are the key ideas behind ML agents?

ML agents in modern systems can orchestrate tools and models to perform complex tasks, not just single predictions. They may call external APIs, reason over intermediate results, and plan multi-step actions.
Give an example of softmax regression

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.
How does reinforcement learning relate to other concepts?

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.
Explain ML monitoring.

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
Give a concise definition of serverless ML.

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
Give a concise definition of LSTM networks.
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about feature stores?

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
Explain transformers and self-attention

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.
What are the advantages of understanding AutoML well?

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.
Why is real-time machine learning important in modern machine learning systems?

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.
What are the key ideas behind backpropagation?

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

What are the advantages of understanding real-time machine learning well?

Real-time machine learning refers to systems that make low-latency predictions in response to live events. These systems often use streaming features, online feature stores, and efficient deployment frameworks.
How does gradient descent relate to other concepts?

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.
Give an example of serverless ML

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
Explain AutoML.

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.
How does convolutional neural networks relate to other concepts?

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.
Give a concise definition of pooling layers.
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.
Explain convolutional neural networks.

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about LSTM networks?
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
Explain logistic regression

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.
How does unsupervised learning relate to other concepts?

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.
What are the key ideas behind reinforcement learning?

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.
Why is logistic regression important in modern machine learning systems?

What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about convolutional neural networks?

What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about ML monitoring?

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
Describe a practical use case where convolutional neural networks is applied.

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.
Explain transformers and self-attention.

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.
How does train–serve skew relate to other concepts?

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.

Explain supervised learning.

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.
Why is reinforcement learning important in modern machine learning systems?

Why is gradient descent important in modern machine learning systems?

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.
Describe a practical use case where activation functions is applied.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.
What are the key ideas behind model-centric vs data-centric iteration?

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.

Give an example of linear regression

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

What are the key ideas behind serverless ML?

Serverless ML uses managed compute services to run ML workloads without manual server provisioning. It simplifies scaling, reduces operational burden, and is well-suited for sporadic or bursty workloads.
Give a concise definition of feature stores.

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.
What are the advantages of understanding logistic regression well?

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.
Explain gradient descent

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.
Why is transformers and self-attention important in modern machine learning systems?

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.
Explain train–serve skew

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.
What common mistakes do students make when reasoning about convolutional neural networks?

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) use convolutional layers with shared weights and local connectivity, making them highly effective for image data. They learn hierarchical feature representations, from edges and textures to objects.

Reinforcement learning studies agents that interact with an environment over time, taking actions and receiving rewards. The agent's objective is to learn a policy that maximizes cumulative reward. RL problems are often modeled as Markov decision processes.

How does activation functions relate to other concepts?

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.
What are the key ideas behind pooling layers?
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.

What are the key ideas behind supervised learning?

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.

Logistic regression is a linear classifier that models the probability of a binary outcome using the sigmoid function. It outputs probabilities between 0 and 1 and is trained using a loss such as cross-entropy. Despite its name, it is a classification method.
Explain supervised learning

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.
Explain softmax regression.

Softmax regression, or multinomial logistic regression, generalizes logistic regression to multi-class problems. It uses a softmax function to convert class scores into a probability distribution over classes.
Why is model-centric vs data-centric iteration important in modern machine learning systems?

Model-centric iteration focuses on changing model architectures or hyperparameters, while data-centric iteration improves the dataset via better labels, more coverage, or refined features. Both are important, but data-centric work is often underemphasized.
Explain LSTM networks
LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory) networks are a type of RNN designed to combat vanishing gradients. They use gating mechanisms and a cell state to preserve information over long time intervals.
Explain supervised learning

Supervised learning is a paradigm where a model is trained on input–output pairs. Each example consists of features x and a target label y. The goal is to learn a function that maps x to y and generalizes well to unseen data. Common tasks include regression and classification.
How does train–serve skew relate to other concepts?

Train–serve skew is the mismatch between training-time and serving-time data or feature computation. It leads to degraded performance in production when the model sees different distributions or feature logic than during training.
Explain ML monitoring?

ML monitoring tracks model performance and data characteristics in production. It includes monitoring for data drift, label shift, latency, and resource usage, so that issues can be detected and addressed promptly.
Describe a practical use case where linear regression is applied.

Linear regression models a real-valued output as a linear combination of input features plus a bias term. Parameters are typically learned by minimizing mean squared error on a training set. It is one of the simplest and most interpretable supervised learning models.
Give a concise definition of feedforward neural networks.

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.
Explain unsupervised learning.

Unsupervised learning deals with datasets without explicit labels. The goal is to discover structure in the data, such as clusters, low-dimensional manifolds, or latent variables. Examples include k-means clustering and PCA.
Give an example of feedforward neural networks

Feedforward neural networks consist of layers of units where information flows from inputs to outputs without cycles. Each hidden layer applies an affine transformation followed by a nonlinearity. With sufficient width and depth, they are universal approximators.
How does transformers and self-attention relate to other concepts?

Transformers are sequence models that rely on self-attention instead of recurrence. Self-attention allows each position in a sequence to attend to all others in parallel, enabling efficient modeling of long-range dependencies.
Explain backpropagation

Backpropagation is the algorithm used to compute gradients in neural networks. It applies the chain rule efficiently across layers, propagating error signals from the output back to earlier layers so all parameters can be updated.

Why is AutoML important in modern machine learning systems?

AutoML (Automated Machine Learning) tools automate parts of the ML pipeline such as model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and feature engineering. They aim to make it easier to obtain high-quality models with less manual experimentation.
Why is feature stores important in modern machine learning systems?

Feature stores are systems that manage ML features for reuse across training and inference. They standardize feature definitions, provide data quality guarantees, and reduce train–serve skew by serving the same features in both phases.

Give an example of pooling layers
Pooling layers reduce the spatial dimensions of feature maps by summarizing regions, typically via max or average pooling. They provide translation invariance and reduce computation and overfitting.
Explain gradient descent

Gradient descent is an iterative optimization algorithm that updates parameters in the direction of the negative gradient of a loss function. Variants include batch, stochastic, and mini-batch gradient descent, as well as adaptive methods like Adam.

Give a concise definition of activation functions.

Activation functions introduce nonlinearity into neural networks. Common choices include ReLU, sigmoid, and tanh. Without nonlinear activations, a deep network collapses to an effective linear model, limiting its expressiveness.
